bestBHT.bht: On the day of his glorious return, the Lord himself will serve his redeemed ones, displaying the fullness of his grace and love. This humble act of service completely reverses human expectations and emphasizes the joyful attendance of the Bridegroom to his friends, even as a servant. It reminds us of the washing of the disciples' feet, serving as a foreshadowing and providing a profound lesson in humility. Jesus will lovingly and honorably serve his faithful servants, bestowing upon them the blessedness of his favor.

Henry Alford: The Lord Himself, in that great day of his glory,—the marriage-supper of the Lamb,—will invert the order of human requirements and in the fulness of his grace and love will serve his brethren."
The Redeemer, his redeemed,—the Shepherd, his flock."
Compare the washing of the disciples’ feet in John xiii. 1 ff., which was a foreshewing of this last great act of self-abasing love.
Jamieson-Fausset-Brown: promise the most august of all: Thus will the Bridegroom entertain
his friends (nay, servants) on the solemn Nuptial Day" [BENGEL].
Albert Barnes: Shall gird himself - Shall take the place of the servant himself... Servants who waited on the table were girded in the manner described above.

Shall make them sit ... - Shall place them at his table and feast them... It will be as if a master, instead of sitting down at the table 'himself,' should place his faithful 'servants' there, and be himself the servant.
This shows the exceeding kindness and condescension of our Lord... How should our bosoms burn with gratitude to him, and how should 'we' be willing to serve one another!
Marvin Vincent: Gird himself. As a servant girding up his loose garments to wait on the table.
Philip Schaff: The blessedness of these faithful servants is set forth in a figure.
Comp. John 13:4, which foreshadows the ministering condescension of the master, at His return.
Serve them, wait upon them at table. In this passage no prominence is given to the wedding feast, and this must be remembered in interpreting it.
Archibald T. Robertson: Jesus did this (John 13:4), not out of gratitude, but to give the apostles an object lesson in humility.
See the usual course in Luke 17:7-10 with also the direct middle (verse Luke 12:8) of περισωννυω.
John Gill: Such servants are happy, they will appear to be in the favour of their master, who will take notice of them and show some marks of respect to them.
He shall readily, cheerfully, and at once introduce his servants into his joy, and make them partakers of all the glories of the other world.
He shall come forth and serve them; with food, yea, will feed them himself, and lead them to fountains of living water.
John Wesley: He will come and serve them — The meaning is, he will show them his love, in the most condescending and tender manner.

bhtAttempts.bht: On the day of his glorious return, the Lord himself will serve his redeemed ones, reversing the order of human expectations and displaying the fullness of his grace and love. It is a picture of the Bridegroom joyfully attending to his friends, even taking the role of a servant. This act of humble service echoes the washing of the disciples' feet as a foreshadowing of his ultimate act of love. Just as Jesus demonstrated humility in washing his disciples' feet, he will again humbly serve his faithful servants on the Nuptial Day. It is a promise of utmost honor and a display of the blessedness of those in favor with their master.

On the day of his glorious return, the Lord himself will serve his redeemed ones, reversing human expectations and displaying the fullness of his grace and love. It is a picture of the Bridegroom joyfully attending to his friends, even as a servant. This act of humble service echoes the washing of the disciples' feet as a foreshadowing. Just as Jesus demonstrated humility by washing the disciples' feet, he will again humbly serve his faithful servants, offering an object lesson in humility and promising the utmost honor.

On the day of his glorious return, the Lord himself will serve his redeemed ones, displaying the fullness of his grace and love. This act of humble service is a reversal of human expectations, symbolizing the joyful attendance of the Bridegroom to his friends, even as a servant. It echoes the washing of the disciples' feet as a foreshadowing, demonstrating humility and offering an object lesson. Jesus will once again serve his faithful servants, promising the utmost honor and blessedness to those in his favor.

On the day of his glorious return, the Lord himself will serve his redeemed ones, displaying the fullness of his grace and love. This humble act of service completely reverses human expectations and emphasizes the joyful attendance of the Bridegroom to his friends, even as a servant. It reminds us of the washing of the disciples' feet, serving as a foreshadowing and providing a profound lesson in humility. Jesus will lovingly and honorably serve his faithful servants, bestowing upon them the blessedness of his favor.

In the day of his glorious return, the Lord himself will serve his redeemed ones, demonstrating the fullness of his grace and love. As a reversal of human expectations, this act of humble service signifies the Bridegroom's joyful attendance to his friends, taking the role of a servant. It is reminiscent of Jesus washing the disciples' feet, which foreshadowed this ultimate act of self-abasing love. Just as Jesus exemplified humility then, he will once again humbly serve his faithful servants, promising them the highest honor and blessedness.
